Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Story: I stood in the kitchen, my phone pressed between my shoulder and ear, listening to my patient’s anxious voice. She needed reassurance, a new prescription, and a careful adjustment to her treatment plan. My laptop was open on the counter, medical records glowing on the screen. At the same time, I could hear my husband in the living room, vacuuming, his voice strained as he called out for help with the guest room. My mother-in-law was arriving in a few hours, and the house was far from ready. I felt the weight of expectation from both sides—my patient trusting me to manage her health, my family relying on me to make our home welcoming. My mind raced, torn between the urgency of medical care and the unspoken rule that the house must be spotless for guests. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on my patient’s needs, but guilt gnawed at me for not being present with my husband. I could feel the tension building, knowing I couldn’t give my best to both at the same time.
